title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Introduction
content: The nasal cavity is a roughly cylindrical, midline airway passage that extends from the nasal ala anteriorly to the choana posteriorly. [1] It is divided in the midline by the nasal septum. On each side, it is flanked by the maxillary sinuses and roofed by the frontal, ethmoid, and sphenoid sinuses in an anterior to posterior fashion. [1] While seemingly simple, sinonasal anatomy is composed of intricate and subdivided air passages and drainage pathways that connect the sinuses.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Introduction. The nasal cavity is a roughly cylindrical, midline airway passage that extends from the nasal ala anteriorly to the choana posteriorly. [1] It is divided in the midline by the nasal septum. On each side, it is flanked by the maxillary sinuses and roofed by the frontal, ethmoid, and sphenoid sinuses in an anterior to posterior fashion. [1] While seemingly simple, sinonasal anatomy is composed of intricate and subdivided air passages and drainage pathways that connect the sinuses.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function
content: There are four paired sinuses in humans, all lined with pseudostratified columnar epithelium: the maxillary sinuses, the largest ones located under the eyes in the maxillary bones; [2] the frontal sinuses, superior to the eyes within the frontal bone; the ethmoid sinuses, formed from several air cells within the ethmoid bone between the nose and eyes; and the sphenoid sinuses, located within the body of the sphenoid bone.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function. There are four paired sinuses in humans, all lined with pseudostratified columnar epithelium: the maxillary sinuses, the largest ones located under the eyes in the maxillary bones; [2] the frontal sinuses, superior to the eyes within the frontal bone; the ethmoid sinuses, formed from several air cells within the ethmoid bone between the nose and eyes; and the sphenoid sinuses, located within the body of the sphenoid bone.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function
content: The function of the paranasal sinuses is debated. However, they are believed to be implicated in several roles: decreasing the relative weight of the skull, increasing the resonance of the voice, providing a buffer against facial trauma, insulating sensitive structures from rapid temperature fluctuations in the nose, and humidifying and heating inspired air. Furthermore, they also play a role in immunological defense.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function. The function of the paranasal sinuses is debated. However, they are believed to be implicated in several roles: decreasing the relative weight of the skull, increasing the resonance of the voice, providing a buffer against facial trauma, insulating sensitive structures from rapid temperature fluctuations in the nose, and humidifying and heating inspired air. Furthermore, they also play a role in immunological defense.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function
content: Learning the anatomical relationships of the sinuses to surrounding structures will develop a strong understanding of paranasal sinus anatomy. The lateral nasal wall contains many structures and recesses that are relevant to paranasal sinus anatomy:
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function. Learning the anatomical relationships of the sinuses to surrounding structures will develop a strong understanding of paranasal sinus anatomy. The lateral nasal wall contains many structures and recesses that are relevant to paranasal sinus anatomy:

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Turbinates
content: They are three to four bony shelves covered by erectile mucosa that increase the interior surface area.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Turbinates. They are three to four bony shelves covered by erectile mucosa that increase the interior surface area.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Meatuses
content: The meatuses are three spaces located beneath each turbinate. The superior meatus drains for the sphenoid and posterior ethmoid sinuses. The middle meatus drains the frontal, anterior ethmoid, and maxillary sinuses. The inferior meatus contains the orifice of the nasolacrimal duct.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Meatuses. The meatuses are three spaces located beneath each turbinate. The superior meatus drains for the sphenoid and posterior ethmoid sinuses. The middle meatus drains the frontal, anterior ethmoid, and maxillary sinuses. The inferior meatus contains the orifice of the nasolacrimal duct.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Uncinate Process
content: The uncinate process is a delicate, sickle-shaped, bony part of the ethmoid bone, covered by mucoperiosteum, medial to the ethmoid infundibulum, and lateral to the middle turbinate. Its anterior attachment corresponds to the lacrimal bone, and its inferior one corresponds to the ethmoidal process of the inferior turbinate and the perpendicular process of the palatine bone. [3] The superior attachment can be inconsistent. [3]
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Uncinate Process. The uncinate process is a delicate, sickle-shaped, bony part of the ethmoid bone, covered by mucoperiosteum, medial to the ethmoid infundibulum, and lateral to the middle turbinate. Its anterior attachment corresponds to the lacrimal bone, and its inferior one corresponds to the ethmoidal process of the inferior turbinate and the perpendicular process of the palatine bone. [3] The superior attachment can be inconsistent. [3]

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Ethmoid Infundibulum
content: The ethmoid infundibulum is a pyramidal space that facilitates the drainage of the maxillary, anterior ethmoid, and frontal sinuses. [4] The superior attachment of the uncinate process determines the spatial relationship of the frontal sinus drainage.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Ethmoid Infundibulum. The ethmoid infundibulum is a pyramidal space that facilitates the drainage of the maxillary, anterior ethmoid, and frontal sinuses. [4] The superior attachment of the uncinate process determines the spatial relationship of the frontal sinus drainage.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Semilunar Hiatus
content: The semilunar hiatus is the gap that empties the ethmoid infundibulum located between the uncinate process and the ethmoid bulla.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Semilunar Hiatus. The semilunar hiatus is the gap that empties the ethmoid infundibulum located between the uncinate process and the ethmoid bulla.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Osteomeatal Complex (OMC)
content: The osteomeatal complex is a lateral nasal wall region that drains the anterior ethmoid cells and the maxillary and frontal sinuses, [4] located lateral to the middle turbinate. It is not a discrete anatomic structure but a collection of several components, including anterior ethmoid air cells, maxillary sinus ostium, ethmoid infundibulum, frontal recess, the middle meatus, the hiatus semilunaris, the bulla ethmoidalis, and the uncinate process. [4] [3] [4]
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Osteomeatal Complex (OMC). The osteomeatal complex is a lateral nasal wall region that drains the anterior ethmoid cells and the maxillary and frontal sinuses, [4] located lateral to the middle turbinate. It is not a discrete anatomic structure but a collection of several components, including anterior ethmoid air cells, maxillary sinus ostium, ethmoid infundibulum, frontal recess, the middle meatus, the hiatus semilunaris, the bulla ethmoidalis, and the uncinate process. [4] [3] [4]

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Nasal Fontanelles
content: The nasal fontanelles are described as an area of the lateral nasal wall where no bone exists. The natural ostium of the maxillary sinus is located in the anterior fontanelle.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Nasal Fontanelles. The nasal fontanelles are described as an area of the lateral nasal wall where no bone exists. The natural ostium of the maxillary sinus is located in the anterior fontanelle.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Maxillary Sinus
content: The maxillary sinus is a pneumatic cavity located in the maxillary bone. [5] It is pyramidal in shape, with a base looking to the nasal cavity, anterior, posterior, and superior walls, and a lateral blunt apex that extends into the zygomatic process of the maxillary bone. The size of the maxillary sinus at the adult stage is approximately 15 mL, [6] making it the largest paranasal sinus.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Maxillary Sinus. The maxillary sinus is a pneumatic cavity located in the maxillary bone. [5] It is pyramidal in shape, with a base looking to the nasal cavity, anterior, posterior, and superior walls, and a lateral blunt apex that extends into the zygomatic process of the maxillary bone. The size of the maxillary sinus at the adult stage is approximately 15 mL, [6] making it the largest paranasal sinus.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Maxillary Sinus
content: The anterior wall corresponds to the facial surface of the maxillary bone, with three clearly identified landmarks – the canine fossa and the infraorbital foramen and groove. The infraorbital foramen is located at 5 to 8 mm below the midpoint of the inferior margin of the orbit. [7] The posterior wall correlates to the maxillary tuberosity, which shapes the anterior surface of the pterygopalatine fossa. [8] The posterior wall is in close relationship with the contents of the pterygopalatine fossa, including the pterygopalatine ganglion and several branches of the maxillary artery, vein, and nerve. [9] Tumors and infections of the maxillary sinus and oral cavity can extend to the pterygopalatine fossa and affect these essential structures.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Maxillary Sinus. The anterior wall corresponds to the facial surface of the maxillary bone, with three clearly identified landmarks – the canine fossa and the infraorbital foramen and groove. The infraorbital foramen is located at 5 to 8 mm below the midpoint of the inferior margin of the orbit. [7] The posterior wall correlates to the maxillary tuberosity, which shapes the anterior surface of the pterygopalatine fossa. [8] The posterior wall is in close relationship with the contents of the pterygopalatine fossa, including the pterygopalatine ganglion and several branches of the maxillary artery, vein, and nerve. [9] Tumors and infections of the maxillary sinus and oral cavity can extend to the pterygopalatine fossa and affect these essential structures.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Maxillary Sinus
content: The superior wall, also known as the sinus roof, is formed by the orbit floor. The infraorbital artery (branch of the maxillary artery) and nerve (branch of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve) run through this wall and enter the infraorbital groove. [9] The medial wall separates the maxillary sinus from the nasal cavity, but they communicate throughout the ostium, located in the medial wall inferior or at the same level of the orbit floor. [9]
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Maxillary Sinus. The superior wall, also known as the sinus roof, is formed by the orbit floor. The infraorbital artery (branch of the maxillary artery) and nerve (branch of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve) run through this wall and enter the infraorbital groove. [9] The medial wall separates the maxillary sinus from the nasal cavity, but they communicate throughout the ostium, located in the medial wall inferior or at the same level of the orbit floor. [9]

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Maxillary Sinus
content: The inferior wall, known as the sinus floor, is in close relation with the posterior teeth apices, from which it is separated only by a layer of compact bone. The mean distance between the dental apices and the sinus floor is 1.97 mm, [10] and the apices of the molars are closer to the sinus floor than the premolars. [10] The first molars have been found to perforate the sinus floor in 2.2% of cases, and the second molars in 2% of cases. The buccodistal root of the second molar is the closest to the maxillary sinus floor. [2]
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Maxillary Sinus. The inferior wall, known as the sinus floor, is in close relation with the posterior teeth apices, from which it is separated only by a layer of compact bone. The mean distance between the dental apices and the sinus floor is 1.97 mm, [10] and the apices of the molars are closer to the sinus floor than the premolars. [10] The first molars have been found to perforate the sinus floor in 2.2% of cases, and the second molars in 2% of cases. The buccodistal root of the second molar is the closest to the maxillary sinus floor. [2]

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Maxillary Sinus
content: The maxillary sinuses frequently present septa, which are thin plates of cortical bone arising from the sinus floor, better visualized on cone-beam CT scans. Primary septa occur during the development of the sinus, [11] whereas secondary septa occur after tooth loss. [12] Apart from septa, tooth loss causes a local lowering of the sinus floor and alveolar bone resorption. [9]
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Maxillary Sinus. The maxillary sinuses frequently present septa, which are thin plates of cortical bone arising from the sinus floor, better visualized on cone-beam CT scans. Primary septa occur during the development of the sinus, [11] whereas secondary septa occur after tooth loss. [12] Apart from septa, tooth loss causes a local lowering of the sinus floor and alveolar bone resorption. [9]

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Maxillary Sinus
content: Mucus-producing ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium lines the maxillary sinus, which lacks periosteum. The cilia have the heavy task of draining the mucous into the ostium (located superiorly in the medial wall), and they are more numerous near the ostium. [2]
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Maxillary Sinus. Mucus-producing ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium lines the maxillary sinus, which lacks periosteum. The cilia have the heavy task of draining the mucous into the ostium (located superiorly in the medial wall), and they are more numerous near the ostium. [2]

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Frontal Sinus
content: The frontal sinus is a highly variable air-filled anatomical structure located superior to the orbit and within the frontal bone. Its shape and size depend on climate and ethnicity but is more or less pyramidal in adults, [13] and the typical volume is 4 to 7 mL. The frontal sinus is divided into two cavities by the frontal septum. Several anatomical structures are important to frontal sinus anatomy, and they include:
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Frontal Sinus. The frontal sinus is a highly variable air-filled anatomical structure located superior to the orbit and within the frontal bone. Its shape and size depend on climate and ethnicity but is more or less pyramidal in adults, [13] and the typical volume is 4 to 7 mL. The frontal sinus is divided into two cavities by the frontal septum. Several anatomical structures are important to frontal sinus anatomy, and they include:

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Frontal Sinus Infundibulum and Ostium
content: The frontal infundibulum is a conically tapering constriction located in the frontal sinus floor, [14] superior to the agger nasi cells, that drains into the frontal recess. It is a transition zone between the frontal sinus and the frontal recess, and its narrowest area is known as the ostium. [15]
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Frontal Sinus Infundibulum and Ostium. The frontal infundibulum is a conically tapering constriction located in the frontal sinus floor, [14] superior to the agger nasi cells, that drains into the frontal recess. It is a transition zone between the frontal sinus and the frontal recess, and its narrowest area is known as the ostium. [15]

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Frontal Recess
content: The frontal recess is the space posterior to the frontal beak into which the frontal sinus drains. [15] It is anteriorly bounded by the posterior wall of the agger nasi cell, laterally by the lamina papyracea, and medially by the middle turbinate. [15] [4] [15]
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Frontal Recess. The frontal recess is the space posterior to the frontal beak into which the frontal sinus drains. [15] It is anteriorly bounded by the posterior wall of the agger nasi cell, laterally by the lamina papyracea, and medially by the middle turbinate. [15] [4] [15]

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Frontal Recess
content: Several cells cover this space and influence the direction of the drainage outflow. [15] The frontal recess is a common site of infection, and its surgical approach is known to be challenging. [4] The recess can open into the middle meatus in more than half of individuals or into the ethmoid infundibulum in the rest. [4]
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Frontal Recess. Several cells cover this space and influence the direction of the drainage outflow. [15] The frontal recess is a common site of infection, and its surgical approach is known to be challenging. [4] The recess can open into the middle meatus in more than half of individuals or into the ethmoid infundibulum in the rest. [4]

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Frontal Cells
content: In 2016 a group of experts developed The International Frontal Sinus Anatomy Classification (IFAC) [15] to provide a better understanding to the surgeon about the variable and complicated frontal sinus recess and frontal sinus anatomy. The resulting classification is described below:
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Frontal Cells. In 2016 a group of experts developed The International Frontal Sinus Anatomy Classification (IFAC) [15] to provide a better understanding to the surgeon about the variable and complicated frontal sinus recess and frontal sinus anatomy. The resulting classification is described below:

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Anterior Cells
content: The anterior cells are formed by the agger nasi cell, supra agger cell, and supra agger frontal cell. They push the drainage in a medial, posterior, or posteromedial direction.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Anterior Cells. The anterior cells are formed by the agger nasi cell, supra agger cell, and supra agger frontal cell. They push the drainage in a medial, posterior, or posteromedial direction.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Agger Nasi Cell
content: The most anterior ethmoidal cell is known as Agger nasi cell. [15] Almost all patients have this cell, which is an ethmoturbinal remnant; to accurately view the frontal recess, the agger nasi cells need to be opened. [4] The agger nasi cell can be located: 1) anterior to the middle turbinate origin or 2) directly superior to the most anterior middle turbinate insertion into the lateral nasal wall.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Agger Nasi Cell. The most anterior ethmoidal cell is known as Agger nasi cell. [15] Almost all patients have this cell, which is an ethmoturbinal remnant; to accurately view the frontal recess, the agger nasi cells need to be opened. [4] The agger nasi cell can be located: 1) anterior to the middle turbinate origin or 2) directly superior to the most anterior middle turbinate insertion into the lateral nasal wall.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Supra Agger Cell
content: This is an anterior-lateral ethmoidal cell that sits superior to the agger nasi cell but does not pneumatize into the frontal sinus.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Supra Agger Cell. This is an anterior-lateral ethmoidal cell that sits superior to the agger nasi cell but does not pneumatize into the frontal sinus.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Supra Agger Frontal Cell
content: This is an anterior lateral ethmoidal cell extending into the frontal sinus. The level of extension of these cells into the frontal sinus depends on their size. If small, it usually only extends into the sinus floor. If large, it extends more into the sinus, elongating even into the sinus roof.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Supra Agger Frontal Cell. This is an anterior lateral ethmoidal cell extending into the frontal sinus. The level of extension of these cells into the frontal sinus depends on their size. If small, it usually only extends into the sinus floor. If large, it extends more into the sinus, elongating even into the sinus roof.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Posterior Cells
content: The posterior cells include supra bulla cell, supra bulla frontal cell, and supraorbital ethmoid cell. They push the drainage in an anterior direction.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Posterior Cells. The posterior cells include supra bulla cell, supra bulla frontal cell, and supraorbital ethmoid cell. They push the drainage in an anterior direction.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Supra Bulla Cell
content: It sits superior to the bulla ethmoidalis and does not enter the frontal sinus.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Supra Bulla Cell. It sits superior to the bulla ethmoidalis and does not enter the frontal sinus.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Supra Bulla Frontal Cell
content: The origin of this cell is the supra bulla region, hence its name; it pneumatizes into the frontal sinus posterior area. The posterior wall of this cell is the skull base.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Supra Bulla Frontal Cell. The origin of this cell is the supra bulla region, hence its name; it pneumatizes into the frontal sinus posterior area. The posterior wall of this cell is the skull base.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Supraorbital Ethmoid Cell
content: This is an anterior ethmoid cell that pneumatizes anterior, posterior, or around the anterior ethmoidal artery on the orbit's roof. If the frontal sinus is extensively pneumatized, the supraorbital ethmoid cell may be a part of the sinus' posterior wall, requiring bony septation to separate it from the sinus.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Supraorbital Ethmoid Cell. This is an anterior ethmoid cell that pneumatizes anterior, posterior, or around the anterior ethmoidal artery on the orbit's roof. If the frontal sinus is extensively pneumatized, the supraorbital ethmoid cell may be a part of the sinus' posterior wall, requiring bony septation to separate it from the sinus.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Medial Cells
content: The frontal septal cells are classified as medial cells. These are medially based cells of the inferior frontal sinus or the anterior ethmoid sinus; they are attached to the interfrontal sinus septum. They push the drainage in a lateral and often posterior direction.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Medial Cells. The frontal septal cells are classified as medial cells. These are medially based cells of the inferior frontal sinus or the anterior ethmoid sinus; they are attached to the interfrontal sinus septum. They push the drainage in a lateral and often posterior direction.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Sphenoid Sinus
content: The sphenoid sinus is located centrally and posteriorly within the body of the sphenoid bone, [16] and it is posteriorly and superiorly bounded by the sella turcica. The sphenoid sinus, present only in humans and primates, [16] can be identified in radiographs from the age of two. [17] It keeps developing throughout life but matures in size at around 12 to 14 years of age. [16] The typical adult size is 0.5 to 8 mL. Several important structures have a close relation to the sphenoid sinus, including the internal carotid artery and the optic nerve. [18]
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Sphenoid Sinus. The sphenoid sinus is located centrally and posteriorly within the body of the sphenoid bone, [16] and it is posteriorly and superiorly bounded by the sella turcica. The sphenoid sinus, present only in humans and primates, [16] can be identified in radiographs from the age of two. [17] It keeps developing throughout life but matures in size at around 12 to 14 years of age. [16] The typical adult size is 0.5 to 8 mL. Several important structures have a close relation to the sphenoid sinus, including the internal carotid artery and the optic nerve. [18]

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Sphenoid Sinus
content: The carotid artery is located adjacent to the lateral wall of the sinus, and in 25% of patients, it is dehiscent in this area. The optic nerve leaves an anteroposterior indentation on the roof of the sphenoid, and the overlying bone can be dehiscent in around 4% of individuals. [18] The sphenoid sinus is also adjacent to the cavernous sinus and hypophysial gland. [16] The patterns of the sphenoidal sinus pneumatization were classified into conchal, pre-sellar, and sellar, depending on the extension of pneumatization concerning the sella turcica. But, Štokovic et al. added a fourth type – post-sellar. [19] The sphenoid ostium drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess located within the superior meatus.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Sphenoid Sinus. The carotid artery is located adjacent to the lateral wall of the sinus, and in 25% of patients, it is dehiscent in this area. The optic nerve leaves an anteroposterior indentation on the roof of the sphenoid, and the overlying bone can be dehiscent in around 4% of individuals. [18] The sphenoid sinus is also adjacent to the cavernous sinus and hypophysial gland. [16] The patterns of the sphenoidal sinus pneumatization were classified into conchal, pre-sellar, and sellar, depending on the extension of pneumatization concerning the sella turcica. But, Štokovic et al. added a fourth type – post-sellar. [19] The sphenoid ostium drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess located within the superior meatus.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Ethmoid Sinuses
content: The ethmoid bone is formed by a multitude of cells with an intricated structure, through which all the paranasal sinuses drain. [20] There are 3 to 4 ethmoid air cells at birth that develop into 5 to 15 paired cells by adulthood with a total volume of 2 to 3 mL. They are located between the eyes, on either side of the septum. The anterior ethmoid cells drain into the ethmoid infundibulum, in the middle meatus. [21] The posterior ethmoid cells drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess located in the superior meatus. The complex ethmoidal labyrinth can be reduced into a series of lamellae based on embryologic precursors. These lamellae are obliquely oriented and lie parallel to each other.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Ethmoid Sinuses. The ethmoid bone is formed by a multitude of cells with an intricated structure, through which all the paranasal sinuses drain. [20] There are 3 to 4 ethmoid air cells at birth that develop into 5 to 15 paired cells by adulthood with a total volume of 2 to 3 mL. They are located between the eyes, on either side of the septum. The anterior ethmoid cells drain into the ethmoid infundibulum, in the middle meatus. [21] The posterior ethmoid cells drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess located in the superior meatus. The complex ethmoidal labyrinth can be reduced into a series of lamellae based on embryologic precursors. These lamellae are obliquely oriented and lie parallel to each other.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Ethmoid Sinuses
content: The first lamella is the uncinate process. The second lamella corresponds to the ethmoid bulla. The third lamella is also known as the basal or ground lamella of the middle turbinate. It serves as the division of the anterior and posterior ethmoids. [22] The anterior part inserts vertically into the crista ethmoidalis. The middle portion attaches obliquely into the lamina papyracea. The posterior third attaches to the lamina papyracea as well but in a horizontal fashion. The fourth lamella is the superior turbinate.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Ethmoid Sinuses. The first lamella is the uncinate process. The second lamella corresponds to the ethmoid bulla. The third lamella is also known as the basal or ground lamella of the middle turbinate. It serves as the division of the anterior and posterior ethmoids. [22] The anterior part inserts vertically into the crista ethmoidalis. The middle portion attaches obliquely into the lamina papyracea. The posterior third attaches to the lamina papyracea as well but in a horizontal fashion. The fourth lamella is the superior turbinate.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Ethmoid Sinuses
content: The agger nasi cell is the most anterior of the anterior ethmoid cells. [15] It is found anterior and superior to the middle turbinate attachment to the lateral wall. The posterior wall of the agger nasi cell forms the anterior wall of the frontal recess. The ethmoid bulla is the largest of the anterior ethmoid cells that lies above the infundibulum - the anterior ethmoid artery courses over the roof of this cell.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Structure and Function -- Ethmoid Sinuses. The agger nasi cell is the most anterior of the anterior ethmoid cells. [15] It is found anterior and superior to the middle turbinate attachment to the lateral wall. The posterior wall of the agger nasi cell forms the anterior wall of the frontal recess. The ethmoid bulla is the largest of the anterior ethmoid cells that lies above the infundibulum - the anterior ethmoid artery courses over the roof of this cell.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Embryology
content: Paranasal sinuses' development is heralded by the appearance of a series of folds on the lateral nasal wall at approximately the eighth week of gestation, known as the ethmoturbinals. Six to seven folds emerge initially, but eventually, only three to four persist through regression and fusion. First ethmoturbinal: they are rudimentary and incomplete in humans. The ascending portion forms the agger nasi descending portion forms the uncinate process. Second ethmoturbinal: it forms the middle turbinate. Third ethmoturbinal: it forms the superior turbinate. Fourth and fifth ethmoturbinals: they fuse to form the supreme turbinate. As development progresses, furrows form between these ethmoturbinals, which establishes rudimentary meati and recesses. The frontal sinus originates from the anterior pneumatization of the frontal recess into the frontal bone. The frontal sinus does not appear until the age of 5 to 6 years old.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Embryology. Paranasal sinuses' development is heralded by the appearance of a series of folds on the lateral nasal wall at approximately the eighth week of gestation, known as the ethmoturbinals. Six to seven folds emerge initially, but eventually, only three to four persist through regression and fusion. First ethmoturbinal: they are rudimentary and incomplete in humans. The ascending portion forms the agger nasi descending portion forms the uncinate process. Second ethmoturbinal: it forms the middle turbinate. Third ethmoturbinal: it forms the superior turbinate. Fourth and fifth ethmoturbinals: they fuse to form the supreme turbinate. As development progresses, furrows form between these ethmoturbinals, which establishes rudimentary meati and recesses. The frontal sinus originates from the anterior pneumatization of the frontal recess into the frontal bone. The frontal sinus does not appear until the age of 5 to 6 years old.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Embryology
content: The sphenoid sinus develops during the third month of gestation. During this time, the nasal mucosa invaginates into the posterior portion of the cartilaginous nasal capsule to form a pouch-like cavity. The wall surrounding this cartilage is ossified in the later months of fetal development. Then, during the second and third years of life, the cartilage is resorbed, and the cavity becomes attached to the body of the sphenoid.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Embryology. The sphenoid sinus develops during the third month of gestation. During this time, the nasal mucosa invaginates into the posterior portion of the cartilaginous nasal capsule to form a pouch-like cavity. The wall surrounding this cartilage is ossified in the later months of fetal development. Then, during the second and third years of life, the cartilage is resorbed, and the cavity becomes attached to the body of the sphenoid.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Embryology
content: By the sixth or seventh year of life, pneumatization of the sphenoid sinus progresses. By twelve years of age, the pneumatization is complete with pneumatization of the anterior clinoids and pterygoid process. [16]
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Embryology. By the sixth or seventh year of life, pneumatization of the sphenoid sinus progresses. By twelve years of age, the pneumatization is complete with pneumatization of the anterior clinoids and pterygoid process. [16]

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Embryology
content: The maxillary sinus starts developing during the 10th week of intrauterine life. [2] The ethmoid infundibulum invaginations towards the mesenchyme fuse during the 11th week of development, forming one oval cavity with smooth walls – the primordium of the maxillary sinus. [23]  The sinus ossification starts during the 16th week. [23] The maxillary sinus shows a biphasic growth pattern at 3 and 7 to 18 years of age. The ethmoid sinuses are comprised of three to four air cells at birth. By the time an individual reaches adulthood, they consist of 1 to 15 aerated cells.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Embryology. The maxillary sinus starts developing during the 10th week of intrauterine life. [2] The ethmoid infundibulum invaginations towards the mesenchyme fuse during the 11th week of development, forming one oval cavity with smooth walls – the primordium of the maxillary sinus. [23]  The sinus ossification starts during the 16th week. [23] The maxillary sinus shows a biphasic growth pattern at 3 and 7 to 18 years of age. The ethmoid sinuses are comprised of three to four air cells at birth. By the time an individual reaches adulthood, they consist of 1 to 15 aerated cells.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Blood Supply and Lymphatics
content: The maxillary sinus is irrigated by branches of the maxillary artery: the infraorbital artery, the posterior superior alveolar artery (PSAA), and the posterior lateral nasal artery. [24]
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Blood Supply and Lymphatics. The maxillary sinus is irrigated by branches of the maxillary artery: the infraorbital artery, the posterior superior alveolar artery (PSAA), and the posterior lateral nasal artery. [24]

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Blood Supply and Lymphatics
content: The infraorbital artery travels through the infraorbital groove and canal and then through the infraorbital foramen. [24] The posterior superior alveolar artery runs along the sinus’ medial wall. The posterior lateral nasal artery can also be found within the medial wall of the maxillary sinus. [24] The maxillary sinus’ innervation is provided by branches of the maxillary nerve: middle, anterior, and posterior superior alveolar nerves, and infraorbital nerve. [2] The frontal sinus vasculature consists of the supraorbital and supratrochlear arteries and ophthalmic and supraorbital veins. The sphenopalatine artery supplies the sphenoid sinus, and venous drainage is via the maxillary vein.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Blood Supply and Lymphatics. The infraorbital artery travels through the infraorbital groove and canal and then through the infraorbital foramen. [24] The posterior superior alveolar artery runs along the sinus’ medial wall. The posterior lateral nasal artery can also be found within the medial wall of the maxillary sinus. [24] The maxillary sinus’ innervation is provided by branches of the maxillary nerve: middle, anterior, and posterior superior alveolar nerves, and infraorbital nerve. [2] The frontal sinus vasculature consists of the supraorbital and supratrochlear arteries and ophthalmic and supraorbital veins. The sphenopalatine artery supplies the sphenoid sinus, and venous drainage is via the maxillary vein.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Blood Supply and Lymphatics
content: The ethmoid sinuses are supplied by the anterior and posterior ethmoid arteries, respectively. These arteries are branches of the ophthalmic artery, a branch of the internal carotid artery. Ethmoid sinus venous drainage is done by the maxillary and ethmoid veins.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Blood Supply and Lymphatics. The ethmoid sinuses are supplied by the anterior and posterior ethmoid arteries, respectively. These arteries are branches of the ophthalmic artery, a branch of the internal carotid artery. Ethmoid sinus venous drainage is done by the maxillary and ethmoid veins.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Nerves
content: The maxillary sinus' innervation is provided by branches of the maxillary nerve: middle, anterior, and posterior superior alveolar nerves, and infraorbital nerve. [2] The sphenoid sinus' innervation is provided by the sphenopalatine nerve, which comprises parasympathetic fibers and CN V2. The frontal sinus is innervated by the supraorbital and supratrochlear nerves (CNV1). The anterior and posterior ethmoid nerves provide innervation to ethmoid sinuses.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Nerves. The maxillary sinus' innervation is provided by branches of the maxillary nerve: middle, anterior, and posterior superior alveolar nerves, and infraorbital nerve. [2] The sphenoid sinus' innervation is provided by the sphenopalatine nerve, which comprises parasympathetic fibers and CN V2. The frontal sinus is innervated by the supraorbital and supratrochlear nerves (CNV1). The anterior and posterior ethmoid nerves provide innervation to ethmoid sinuses.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Muscles
content: The frontalis muscle runs over the frontal skull and sinus region and is part of the mechanism of facial expression. The levator muscles of the lips are anchored over the maxillary sinuses. The zygomatic projection of the maxilla is part of the anchorage of the masseter muscle, a powerful closure of the jaw.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Muscles. The frontalis muscle runs over the frontal skull and sinus region and is part of the mechanism of facial expression. The levator muscles of the lips are anchored over the maxillary sinuses. The zygomatic projection of the maxilla is part of the anchorage of the masseter muscle, a powerful closure of the jaw.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants
content: Nasal anatomy differs significantly among individuals; certain anatomic variations are relatively common. The variations may contribute to mechanical obstruction of the osteomeatal complex leading to rhinosinusitis.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants. Nasal anatomy differs significantly among individuals; certain anatomic variations are relatively common. The variations may contribute to mechanical obstruction of the osteomeatal complex leading to rhinosinusitis.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants
content: Concha bullosa is defined as aeration of the middle turbinate. [4] This variation can be either unilateral or bilateral. If large, a concha bullosa may lead to obstruction of the middle meatus or infundibulum.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants. Concha bullosa is defined as aeration of the middle turbinate. [4] This variation can be either unilateral or bilateral. If large, a concha bullosa may lead to obstruction of the middle meatus or infundibulum.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants
content: The nasal septal deviation is an asymmetric bowing of the nasal cartilaginous septum. Such bowing may compress the middle turbinate in a lateral fashion, which may lead to narrowing of the middle meatus. This variation is often congenital, but may also be secondary to nasal trauma.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants. The nasal septal deviation is an asymmetric bowing of the nasal cartilaginous septum. Such bowing may compress the middle turbinate in a lateral fashion, which may lead to narrowing of the middle meatus. This variation is often congenital, but may also be secondary to nasal trauma.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants
content: The middle turbinate usually curves medially toward the nasal septum. However, when the turbinate curves laterally, the resultant anatomic variant is known as a paradoxical middle turbinate. Such a variant can narrow or obstruct the nasal cavity, middle meatus, or infundibulum.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants. The middle turbinate usually curves medially toward the nasal septum. However, when the turbinate curves laterally, the resultant anatomic variant is known as a paradoxical middle turbinate. Such a variant can narrow or obstruct the nasal cavity, middle meatus, or infundibulum.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants
content: The uncinate process is a structure that has multiple variations between individual patients. The superior attachment of the uncinate process has three major variations that help determine the anatomic configuration of the frontal recess and its drainage:
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants. The uncinate process is a structure that has multiple variations between individual patients. The superior attachment of the uncinate process has three major variations that help determine the anatomic configuration of the frontal recess and its drainage:

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants
content: An uncinate process that extends laterally to attach to the lamina papyracea or the ethmoid bulla, forming a terminal recess of the infundibulum with the frontal recess opening directly into the middle meatus An uncinate process that extends medially and attaches to the lateral surface of the middle turbinate, with the frontal recess draining into the infundibulum An uncinate process that extends medially and superiorly to directly attached to the skull base, with the frontal recess draining into the infundibulum Eighty percent of the time, the uncinate attaches to the lamina papyracea resulting in frontal sinus drainage medial to the uncinate, while 20% of the time, the uncinate attaches to either the skull base or middle turbinate, resulting in drainage lateral to the uncinate.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants. An uncinate process that extends laterally to attach to the lamina papyracea or the ethmoid bulla, forming a terminal recess of the infundibulum with the frontal recess opening directly into the middle meatus An uncinate process that extends medially and attaches to the lateral surface of the middle turbinate, with the frontal recess draining into the infundibulum An uncinate process that extends medially and superiorly to directly attached to the skull base, with the frontal recess draining into the infundibulum Eighty percent of the time, the uncinate attaches to the lamina papyracea resulting in frontal sinus drainage medial to the uncinate, while 20% of the time, the uncinate attaches to either the skull base or middle turbinate, resulting in drainage lateral to the uncinate.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants
content: Haller cells are ethmoid air cells that extend laterally over the medial aspect of the roof of the maxillary sinus. If large enough, they may cause narrowing of the infundibulum. Onodi cells are lateral and posterior extensions of the posterior ethmoid cells. Horizontal septations around the sphenoid sinus delineate them. Importantly, these cells may surround the optic nerve tract, which can increase the risk of injury to the optic nerve during surgery.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants. Haller cells are ethmoid air cells that extend laterally over the medial aspect of the roof of the maxillary sinus. If large enough, they may cause narrowing of the infundibulum. Onodi cells are lateral and posterior extensions of the posterior ethmoid cells. Horizontal septations around the sphenoid sinus delineate them. Importantly, these cells may surround the optic nerve tract, which can increase the risk of injury to the optic nerve during surgery.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants
content: Lastly, the height of the ethmoid roof can vary between patients and vary between each side in the same patient. When there is asymmetry of ethmoid roof height in a patient, the risk of intracranial penetration during FESS is higher.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants. Lastly, the height of the ethmoid roof can vary between patients and vary between each side in the same patient. When there is asymmetry of ethmoid roof height in a patient, the risk of intracranial penetration during FESS is higher.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants
content: These are only a few of the anatomic variations seen in sinonasal anatomy. While they represent the most common variations, the importance of having a sound understanding of the tridimensional anatomy is paramount to safe and effective endoscopic sinus surgery.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Physiologic Variants. These are only a few of the anatomic variations seen in sinonasal anatomy. While they represent the most common variations, the importance of having a sound understanding of the tridimensional anatomy is paramount to safe and effective endoscopic sinus surgery.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Clinical Significance
content: Paranasal sinuses are prone to inflammation and infection. The mucus drainage is interrupted when the paranasal sinuses become blocked from secretions or a mass, causing sinusitis. Depending on the cause, sinusitis is treated with corticosteroids, decongestants, nasal irrigation, and hydration. Rarely surgical intervention is required to enhance drainage.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Clinical Significance. Paranasal sinuses are prone to inflammation and infection. The mucus drainage is interrupted when the paranasal sinuses become blocked from secretions or a mass, causing sinusitis. Depending on the cause, sinusitis is treated with corticosteroids, decongestants, nasal irrigation, and hydration. Rarely surgical intervention is required to enhance drainage.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Clinical Significance
content: Malignancies of the paranasal sinuses are rare. The majority of cancers occur in the maxillary sinus and are more common in men than women. Maxillary sinus malignancies occur between ages 45 to 70, and the most frequent is a sarcoma. Even though metastases are rare, these malignancies are locally invasive and destructive. Diagnosis in most cases is delayed, and the prognosis is poor.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Clinical Significance. Malignancies of the paranasal sinuses are rare. The majority of cancers occur in the maxillary sinus and are more common in men than women. Maxillary sinus malignancies occur between ages 45 to 70, and the most frequent is a sarcoma. Even though metastases are rare, these malignancies are locally invasive and destructive. Diagnosis in most cases is delayed, and the prognosis is poor.

title: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Clinical Significance
content: Acute rhinosinusitis (ARS) and chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) are symptomatic inflammation of the nose and paranasal sinuses. The two are distinguished based on the duration of the complaints. Generally speaking, acute rhinosinusitis is widely considered to be an infectious disorder. On the other hand, chronic rhinosinusitis is typically defined as an inflammatory disorder. In acute rhinosinusitis, the underlying etiology is usually viral or bacterial and occasionally fungal. Its pathogenesis involves infection followed by tissue invasion.The most widely accepted classification system divides chronic rhinosinusitis into chronic rhinosinusitis with and without nasal polyps based on nasal endoscopy (CRSwNP and CRSsNP, respectively). [25] Initially, it was believed that CRSsNP was a disease process characterized by persistent inflammation resulting in an incomplete resolution of acute rhinosinusitis. CRSwNP, on the other hand, was thought to be a noninfectious disease process with unclear etiology, perhaps related to atopy. Instead, current research has revealed that the etiology and pathogenesis of either form of CRS are much more complex.
contents: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Nose Paranasal Sinuses -- Clinical Significance. Acute rhinosinusitis (ARS) and chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) are symptomatic inflammation of the nose and paranasal sinuses. The two are distinguished based on the duration of the complaints. Generally speaking, acute rhinosinusitis is widely considered to be an infectious disorder. On the other hand, chronic rhinosinusitis is typically defined as an inflammatory disorder. In acute rhinosinusitis, the underlying etiology is usually viral or bacterial and occasionally fungal. Its pathogenesis involves infection followed by tissue invasion.The most widely accepted classification system divides chronic rhinosinusitis into chronic rhinosinusitis with and without nasal polyps based on nasal endoscopy (CRSwNP and CRSsNP, respectively). [25] Initially, it was believed that CRSsNP was a disease process characterized by persistent inflammation resulting in an incomplete resolution of acute rhinosinusitis. CRSwNP, on the other hand, was thought to be a noninfectious disease process with unclear etiology, perhaps related to atopy. Instead, current research has revealed that the etiology and pathogenesis of either form of CRS are much more complex.
